Award.AbstractNarration: This award will support student travel to the seventh Midwest Verification Day (MVD), to be held at Iowa State University on October 21-22, 2016. MVD is an informal regional workshop with the goal of cultivating a regional research network in verification and formal methods. The funds will help support U.S. based students, focusing on Ph.D. students at an advanced stage in their program and students who would otherwise not be able to attend MVD. The broader impacts include training the next generation of researchers in this important research area. Higher priority will be assigned to students giving presentations and a strong emphasis will be put on supporting students from underrepresented groups.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 8th Midwest Verification Day workshop was be hosted by the
Department of Computer Science, Iowa State University , in Ames, Iowa on
October 20-21, 2016.

This is an informal workshop on hardware and software verification
(topics include, but are not limited to, model checking, deductive
verification, runtime verification, model based verification,
application of verification techniques) that provides an outlet for
graduate and undergraduate students to present their research work (in
early stages) and for researchers and educators to exchange research
ideas.  The purpose of the workshop is to build and strengthen formal
methods and verification community in the Midwest. Anyone interested in the workshop is invited to participate. There is no registration fee.

The final program for the workshop included 28 research presentations, mostly by graduate students from different midwestern universities. There were two keynote presentations, given by Aaron Tomb from Galois and Sagar Chaki from CMU-Software Engineering Institute. The workshop was very well attended with 75 registered participants (47 from outside the host university). 

The NSF funding supported the travel and accommodation for 23 student participants from outside ISU. The post workshop survey indicated that the meeting contributed to the research and education of the participants and the funding support was important for students to be able to attend such meetings.
